subject: Re: [junit] How to Test Private Methods Inside a Class
msgSnippet: Hey Ilja, Separation of concerns is another great reason to put routines in their own class, and in this case I could put the private load method in it s own

Hey Ilja,

Separation of concerns is another great reason to put
routines in their own class, and in this case I could
put the private load method in it's own class, and use
aspects to trigger the load method within the maven
mojo, but ... Here's the code and I'll comment further
on the but below:

    private ComponentDefinition
loadComponentDefinition(File resourceFile) throws
MojoExecutionException {

        ResourceSet resourceSet = new
ResourceSetImpl();

        



        resourceSet.getResourceFactoryRegistry().

        getExtensionToFactoryMap().put(RDNA_EXTENSION,
new XMIResourceFactoryImpl());

        

        Resource resource = 

           
resourceSet.createResource(URI.createFileURI(resourceFile.getAbsolutePath()));

               



        RdnaPackage rdnaPackage =
RdnaPackage.eINSTANCE;

       
resourceSet.getPackageRegistry().put(rdnaPackage.getNsURI(),
rdnaPackage);

        


        try {

            resource.load(null);

        } catch (IOException e1) {

            throw new MojoExecutionException("Could
not read rdna resource.");

        }

               

        ComponentDefinition componentDefinition =

            (ComponentDefinition)
resource.getContents().get(0);

        

        return componentDefinition;    	

    }


This code has a few parameters in it that are specific

to the loading of this type of resource.

First ComponentDefinition:

This is the model of the resource being loaded.

RdnaPackage

This is part of the factory for creating instances of
the model being loaded.

So this method returns an instance of the loaded
model.

In this case the RdnaPackage and ComponentDefinition
have a one to one correspondence, and both are needed
to make use of the loaded model, so I decided just to
keep the method private and test it using the
PriviligedAccessor...

Cheers,
- Ole

--- Ilja Preuss <it@...> wrote:

> Ole Ersoy wrote:
> 
> > The file loading part is in a private method,
> because
> > the load routine is specific to the class that is
> > being tested, and is therefore not useful in a
> utility
> > library.
> 
> Reusability is not the only reason to extract things
> into their own 
> classes, is it?
> 
> > So I just wanted to put the load routine in a
> private
> > method and test it there, then call it from the
> public
> > method.
> 
> Would putting it into its own class have had any
> negative effect?
> 
> 
> Can you show us the load routine?
> 
> Curious, Ilja
>
